utterances: And you also did a lot of work your organization is in Cave City, Kentucky, right?
Well, that's where our headquarters is.
We also have operation in Missouri, Arkansas, California, New Mexico and various other places.
Cave City, it's got a nice ring to it.
It does, in fact.
Dr. Robert Criss is professor of geology at Washington University here in St. Louis.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Hi.
Dr. William Elliott is a cave biologist and resource scientist at the Missouri Department of Conservation in Jefferson City.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Hello.
Was I right, Scott, in that there are 6,000 caves and counting?
Sure, sure, absolutely.
And first, what are the concerns of the privacy advocates that somebody's name should be identified with the photo?
What they're telling me is, it's a matter of privacy.
It's a matter of high creepy factor, if you will - having a company that can identify you simply by your face.
They don't need any other documentation or data about you.
The advocates are saying it's just out of line to go this far.
Because, in effect, once pictures are associated with a name on Facebook, there would be some record of the biometric data of your face.
Exactly.
And it's going to be a large, large database.
Think how many users Facebook has - anywhere from reportedly 500 million to 700 million users worldwide.
So that's a lot of identification going on around the world.
But think of how many of them misspell things or stick their tongues out when they're having their picture taken, or do things that might throw a wrench into all this.
How accurate is this system?
Well, we're going to have to wait and see.
Facebook started testing it in really small groups last December - pretty quietly.
And just last week, they came out and said that they're going to be rolling this out, and they're collecting data.
And we're just going to have to see how it goes.
This isn't the first privacy concern that's been voiced to Facebook.
How do they typically respond to questions like this?
Now, privacy advocates would rather have you be out of it, and then go in and turn it on if that's what you want.
But Facebook says look, we turn it on for everybody because Facebook is about sharing, and we're trying to make it easier to share.
Do we have any idea how many false positives it might generate - how many people look enough like your friend Joe that they'll describe that as your friend Joe?
Ah, we don't know yet.
I guess we're going to have to wait and see.
But you know, I was saying to friends just this weekend, I hope there aren't a lot of people who look just like me doing really embarrassing things in their pictures.
Well, Sharon Gaudin, thank you very much for talking today.
Thank you.
Sharon Gaudin, senior writer for Computerworld, spoke to us from Portland, Maine.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is NPR.
Commentator John Ridley is a big fan of one of America's most freewheeling cities, Las Vegas.
But with the country in recession, he finds that things have slowed quite a bit.
Las Vegas, like the rest of the country, is doing a post-Money Party detox.
And sure, you could make the point with a bunch of dry stats, like the fact that Nevada's foreclosure rate is one of the highest in the nation.

But I prefer a more personal evaluation, comparing Vegas from one fight night to another - the De La Hoya-Mayweather match I attended in May 2007 and the De La Hoya-Pacquiao bout from this past Saturday night.
How hard Vegas has been hit up was immediately evident when I was able to book a room on the Strip for half-off, last minute on a Saturday night.
And speaking of half, my flight out of beautiful downtown Burbank was only half full, and half of those folks were connectors headed on beyond Vegas.
The normally well-populated McCarran Airport was as empty as Ford Field during the fourth quarter of a Detroit Lions game.
Now, a good indicator of the busyness of Vegas is how long the cab lines are.
The one outside the airport was nonexistent.
I stopped by my hotel where, finally, there was a line for check-in, and that probably had more to do with the obvious cutbacks at the front desk.
Throughout the hotel, free drink coupons, reduced admission passes were being handed out as liberally as bailout packages in Washington.
The casino floor itself was a little slow, but lively.
Certainly not as subdued as when I was there just after 9/11.
But this was a fight night.
The joint should have been popping.
Back in 2007, tickets for De La Hoya-Mayweather sold out in a few hours.
For De La Hoya-Pacquiao, I could have reserved a couple of eleventh-hour tickets for face value.
Instead, I procured some tickets from a guy outside the arena at a quadruple discount that put me right on the floor.
The sweet science is best observed close enough, one can see the sweat ejected from a head on the receiving end of a hot jab.
And there were a lot of hot jabs Saturday night.
So compared to a year and a half ago, is Vegas hurting?
Very much so.
And as a Vegas-phile, seeing the city down on one knee is painful to watch.
But with discounted airfare, hotel room, and fight tickets, this might be one of the few times I've traveled to the Meadows and actually made money.
Commentator John Ridley is founding editor of Thatminoritything.com.
His blog, ""Visible Man,"" is on npr.org.
In Egypt, anti-government protesters took to the streets for a third straight day, defying a government ban.
They're calling for a mass rally tomorrow, after Friday prayers.
The activists, many of them young, educated Egyptians, have been demanding a number of reforms, including a higher minimum wage and an end to the state of emergency.
Many are going further, calling for an end to the regime of President Hosni Mubarak.
He's been in power since 1981.
He's now 82 years old.
For some background on what Mubarak's presidency has meant for Egypt, we've brought in Shibley Telhami.
He's professor of International Relations and Middle East Politics at the University of Maryland.
Thanks for coming in.
My pleasure.
These three decades that Hosni Mubarak has been in power, how would you characterize this regime?
You can see privately in diplomatic cables that U.S.
officials call him a dictator.
How would you describe...
Well, he's definitely an autocrat.
There's no question that he's the central authority.
Egypt has certain freedoms that are allowed, including more freedom of expression than many states that we consider dictatorships.
But there is no question that the bulk of the decisions pertaining to national security, to foreign policy, to the constitution of the government are in the hands, ultimately, of the president.
So that's the president.
Here is a taste of how Democrats are responding.
This is Ron Wyden, top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
To hear songs that Sara Tavares performed at NPR in Los Angeles, go to our Web site at npr.org.

But when the American people speak - and I think an analysis ought to be made of this election - and it appears as though the president hasn't got support to pursue the war, then there's no way for them to continue and expect to get congressional support.
So it will not be that we would take initiative and cut the funds and leave our troops stranded.
But, politically, the president has to take another look at his position.
Finally, are you planning to end the president's tax cuts that expire in 2010?
I'm 76 years old and I don't buy green bananas, and I think that what the economy looks like in 2010 will determine what the Ways and Means Committee will be doing in the area of taxes.
I think it's totally irresponsible for tax writers to say today what we're going to do in 2010 without having a clue as to what the economy looks like.
So I'll take it that you're be there in 2010 to make a decision.
Well, I know one thing: Whether I'm there or not, the president won't be there.
So we ought to take a look and really see whether or not the tax cuts that have already been enacted provide enough relief for the middle class and the working poor.
And I am more concerned with removing the Alternative Minimum Tax, which is a threat to our upper middle income workers than I am with what happens in 2010.
Charlie Rangel, thank you so much.
Thank you.
Have a great day.
Congressman Charles Rangel represents New York's 15th District.
